required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Case Collection Study to Support Digital Mammography Image Software Change
clinical_study.official_title: A Multi-center Feature Analysis Study to Compare the Diagnostic Accuracy of Siemens' Image Processing (SIP) Algorithms With Lorad's Image Processing (LIP) Algorithms in Detecting and Characterizing Breast Lesions

brief_summary.textblock: The primary objective of this study is to compare image processing software to support a new image processing software application for a full-field digital mammography (FFDM) system.

primary_outcome.measure: Area Under the Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC) Curve to Compare Diagnostic Accuracy of 2 Algorithms in Breast Cancer Diagnosis
primary_outcome.time_frame: ~1 year. Women with negative or biopsy benign findings at baseline (study entry) were followed for 1 year to confirm the negative status at 1-year follow-up mammography exam. Women diagnosed with cancer were not followed up.
primary_outcome.description: The primary objective of this study was to demonstrate non-inferiority of the Siemens' processing algorithm to Lorad's processing algorithm with regards to readers' diagnostic accuracy in detecting and characterizing breast lesions. The non-inferiority analyses were performed by comparing the area under the ROC curve (AUC) for the two algorithms & to compare false positive marks per subject. The ROC curve incorporates both sensitivity (true positive rate) and specificity (true negative rate) providing a single assessment incorporating both measures. It shows in a graphical way the trade-off between clinical sensitivity and specificity for every possible cut-off for a test, and gives an idea about the benefit of using the test in question. The higher the total area under the curve, the greater the predictive power of the reader assessments. A breast-based analysis was used for the primary AUC comparison in order to obtain additional power by having more normal/benign breasts.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Female
- > 40 years
Exclusion Criteria:
- Pregnant women, or women who may become pregnant
- Mammographic evidence of breast surgery, prior radiation to the breast, needle projection or pre-biopsy markings are evident in the mammogram (but may include breast implants)
- Palpable lesion or one that is visible by another modality
- Inmates

outcome.title: Area Under the Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC) Curve to Compare Diagnostic Accuracy of 2 Algorithms in Breast Cancer Diagnosis
outcome.description: The primary objective of this study was to demonstrate non-inferiority of the Siemens' processing algorithm to Lorad's processing algorithm with regards to readers' diagnostic accuracy in detecting and characterizing breast lesions. The non-inferiority analyses were performed by comparing the area under the ROC curve (AUC) for the two algorithms & to compare false positive marks per subject. The ROC curve incorporates both sensitivity (true positive rate) and specificity (true negative rate) providing a single assessment incorporating both measures. It shows in a graphical way the trade-off between clinical sensitivity and specificity for every possible cut-off for a test, and gives an idea about the benefit of using the test in question. The higher the total area under the curve, the greater the predictive power of the reader assessments. A breast-based analysis was used for the primary AUC comparison in order to obtain additional power by having more normal/benign breasts.
outcome.time_frame: ~1 year. Women with negative or biopsy benign findings at baseline (study entry) were followed for 1 year to confirm the negative status at 1-year follow-up mammography exam. Women diagnosed with cancer were not followed up.

group.title: FFDM Mammography Exam - LIP Algorithm
group.description: Screening or diagnostic Full Field Digital Mammography (FFDM) exam

group.title: FFDM Mammography Exam - SIP Algorithm
group.description: The same 130 raw data images were externally reprocessed with the Siemens processing algorithm.

measure.title: Area Under the Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC) Curve to Compare Diagnostic Accuracy of 2 Algorithms in Breast Cancer Diagnosis
measure.description: The primary objective of this study was to demonstrate non-inferiority of the Siemens' processing algorithm to Lorad's processing algorithm with regards to readers' diagnostic accuracy in detecting and characterizing breast lesions. The non-inferiority analyses were performed by comparing the area under the ROC curve (AUC) for the two algorithms & to compare false positive marks per subject. The ROC curve incorporates both sensitivity (true positive rate) and specificity (true negative rate) providing a single assessment incorporating both measures. It shows in a graphical way the trade-off between clinical sensitivity and specificity for every possible cut-off for a test, and gives an idea about the benefit of using the test in question. The higher the total area under the curve, the greater the predictive power of the reader assessments. A breast-based analysis was used for the primary AUC comparison in order to obtain additional power by having more normal/benign breasts.

group.title: Mammography Exam
group.description: FFDM screening or diagnostic mammography exam

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
